channel.title: Pirate Radio
channel.description: Love the New Yorker? Try this!
channel.itunes:subtitle: For fun
channel.itunes:author: Smol bean

item.title: The Inside Story of Microsoft’s Partnership with OpenAI
item.itunes:summary: The companies had honed a protocol for releasing artificial intelligence ambitiously but safely. Then OpenAI’s board exploded all their carefully laid plans.
item.itunes:author: By Charles Duhigg
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: How to Build a Better Motivational Speaker
item.itunes:summary: The upstart motivator Jesse Itzler wants to reform his profession—while also rising to the top.
item.itunes:author: By Tad Friend
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Makeup Artist Behind Bradley Cooper’s Prosthetic Nose
item.itunes:summary: In the age of C.G.I., the work of effects artists like Kazu Hiro remains meticulously tactile. “I was sort of his canvas” for “Maestro,” Cooper said.
item.itunes:author: By Hua Hsu
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: How Jensen Huang’s Nvidia Is Powering the A.I. Revolution
item.itunes:summary: The company’s C.E.O. bet it all on a new kind of chip. Now that Nvidia is one of the biggest companies in the world, what will he do next?
item.itunes:author: By Stephen Witt
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: What Happens to a School Shooter’s Sister?
item.itunes:summary: Twenty-five years ago, Kristin Kinkel’s brother, Kip, killed their parents and opened fire at their high school. Today, she is close with Kip—and still reckoning with his crimes.
item.itunes:author: By Jennifer Gonnerman
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Dawn of the Celebrity Power Couple
item.itunes:summary: From Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor to Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce, the first rule of the A-list relationship is clear: It always involves more than two people.
item.itunes:author: By Andrew O’Hagan
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Violence of the Rams
item.itunes:summary: I know you can’t hold animals to human standards. That said, rams are assholes.
item.itunes:author: By David Sedaris
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Piecing Together My Father’s Murder
item.itunes:summary: I was too young to remember what happened to my dad, and no one explained it to me. So I tried to assemble the story myself.
item.itunes:author: By Eren Orbey
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Joyce Carol Oates’s Relentless, Prolific Search for a Self
item.itunes:summary: In more than a hundred works of fiction, Oates has investigated the question of personality—while doubting that she actually has one.
item.itunes:author: By Rachel Aviv
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Does A.I. Lead Police to Ignore Contradictory Evidence?
item.itunes:summary: Too often, a facial-recognition search represents virtually the entirety of a police investigation.
item.itunes:author: By Eyal Press
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Why the Godfather of A.I. Fears What He’s Built
item.itunes:summary: Geoffrey Hinton has spent a lifetime teaching computers to learn. Now he worries that artificial brains are better than ours.
item.itunes:author: By Joshua Rothman
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Holly Herndon’s Infinite Art
item.itunes:summary: The artist and musician uses machine learning to make strange, playful work. She also advocates for artists’ autonomy in a world shaped by A.I.
item.itunes:author: By Anna Wiener
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Eclipsed in his Era, Bayard Rustin Gets to Shine in Ours
item.itunes:summary: The civil-rights mastermind was sidelined by his own movement. Now he’s back in the spotlight. What can we learn from his strategies of resistance?
item.itunes:author: By Adam Gopnik
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Reinventing the Dinosaur
item.itunes:summary: “Life on Our Planet,” a new Netflix nature documentary, renews our fascination with our most feared and loved precursors.
item.itunes:author: By Rivka Galchen
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Ridley Scott’s “Napoleon” Complex
item.itunes:summary: Does the director of “Alien,” “Blade Runner,” and “Gladiator” see himself in the hero of his epic new film?
item.itunes:author: By Michael Schulman
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Kingpin Who Kidnapped Migrants for Ransom
item.itunes:summary: An Eritrean trafficker promised to help Africans desperate to reach Europe—then brutalized them inside a Libyan compound while extorting their families back home. With his fortune, he partied in Dubai.
item.itunes:author: By Ed Caesar
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Why Maui Burned
item.itunes:summary: Lahaina’s wildfire was the deadliest in the U.S. in more than a century. Now the community is grappling with the botched response as it tries to rebuild.
item.itunes:author: By Carolyn Kormann
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: In the Cities of Killing
item.itunes:summary: The Hamas massacre, the assaults on Gaza, and what comes after.
item.itunes:author: By David Remnick
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Will the U.A.W. Strike Turn the Rust Belt Green?
item.itunes:summary: A historic walkout against the Big Three automakers could shape the trajectory of one of America’s most politically salient regions.
item.itunes:author: By Dan Kaufman
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Jim Jordan’s Conspiratorial Quest for Power
item.itunes:summary: How the Ohio Republican built an insurgent bid for Speaker on the lies of Donald Trump.
item.itunes:author: By Jonathan Blitzer
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: China’s Age of Malaise
item.itunes:summary: Party officials are vanishing, young workers are “lying flat,” and entrepreneurs are fleeing the country. What does China’s inner turmoil mean for the world?
item.itunes:author: By Evan Osnos
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Great Cash-for-Carbon Hustle
item.itunes:summary: Offsetting has been hailed as a fix for runaway emissions and climate change—but the market’s largest firm sold millions of credits for carbon reductions that weren’t real.
item.itunes:author: By Heidi Blake
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Can Happiness Be Taught?
item.itunes:summary: Bolstered by Oprah, a Harvard Business School professor thinks you should run your inner self like a company.
item.itunes:author: By Anthony Lane
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: A Trans Teen in an Anti-Trans State
item.itunes:summary: One family’s move to find gender-affirming care.
item.itunes:author: By Emily Witt
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Jake Sullivan’s Trial by Combat
item.itunes:summary: Inside the White House’s battle to keep Ukraine in the fight.
item.itunes:author: By Susan B. Glasser
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Among the Cabin Fanatics of Mississippi’s Giant Houseparty
item.itunes:summary: For more than a hundred years, the Neshoba County Fair has drawn revellers from all over the country. Why do they keep coming back?
item.itunes:author: By Paige Williams
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Next Targets for the Group That Overturned Roe
item.itunes:summary: Alliance Defending Freedom has won fifteen Supreme Court cases. Now it wants religious exemptions to anti-discrimination laws—and is going after trans rights.
item.itunes:author: By David D. Kirkpatrick
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: They Studied Dishonesty. Was Their Work a Lie?
item.itunes:summary: Dan Ariely and Francesca Gino became famous for their research into why we bend the truth. Now they’ve both been accused of fabricating data.
item.itunes:author: By Gideon Lewis-Kraus
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Inside Sam Bankman-Fried’s Family Bubble
item.itunes:summary: At Stanford Law School, Joseph Bankman and Barbara Fried specialized in ethics and social fairness. Now that their son stands accused of one of the largest financial frauds in U.S. history, they’re scrambling for legal escape routes.
item.itunes:author: By Sheelah Kolhatkar
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: A Young Architect’s Designs for the Climate Apocalypse
item.itunes:summary: Pavels Hedström believes that most architecture separates us from nature. He wants to make nonhuman life inescapable.
item.itunes:author: By Sam Knight
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Jeremy O. Harris, Before and After “Slave Play”
item.itunes:summary: Harris has forged an unlikely career with sharp institutional critiques. Now he’s almost an institution unto himself.
item.itunes:author: By Vinson Cunningham
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Ross Douthat’s Theories of Persuasion
item.itunes:summary: At a time of distrust and polarization, the conservative Times columnist seeks to bridge the worlds of the Christian right and the secular left.
item.itunes:author: By Isaac Chotiner
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: How Emily Wilson Made Homer Modern
item.itunes:summary: Her vitally urgent translations of the Iliad and the Odyssey strip away the “tarnish of centuries.”
item.itunes:author: By Judith Thurman
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Lies in Your Grocery Store
item.itunes:summary: Most people accept the gimmicks of food labelling. One lawyer can’t stomach them.
item.itunes:author: By Sarah Larson
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Can We Talk to Whales?
item.itunes:summary: Researchers believe that artificial intelligence may allow us to speak to other species.
item.itunes:author: By Elizabeth Kolbert
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Hunt for the Most Elusive Creature in the Sea
item.itunes:summary: The giant squid has taken on a near-mythical status for generations of sailors, explorers, and writers. How could something so big remain unseen—or be less understood than dinosaurs?
item.itunes:author: By David Grann
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: All the Carcinogens We Cannot See
item.itunes:summary: We routinely test for chemicals that cause mutations. What about the dark matter of carcinogens—substances that don’t create cancer cells but rouse them from their slumber?
item.itunes:author: By Siddhartha Mukherjee
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Sentenced to Life for an Accident Miles Away
item.itunes:summary: A draconian legal doctrine called felony murder has put thousands of Americans—disproportionately young and Black—in prison.
item.itunes:author: By Sarah Stillman
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Global Ambitions of Invader’s Street Art
item.itunes:summary: At any given moment, millions of people are attending his expositions, knowingly or not.
item.itunes:author: By Lauren Collins
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The World’s Fastest Road Cars—and the People Who Drive Them
item.itunes:summary: “Hypercars” can approach or even exceed 300 m.p.h. Often costing millions of dollars, they’re ostentatious trophies—and sublime engines of innovation.
item.itunes:author: By Ed Caesar
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: A Palestinian Poet’s Perilous Journey Out of Gaza
item.itunes:summary: Following Hamas’s October 7th attack and Israel’s invasion, Mosab Abu Toha fled his home with his wife and three children. Then I.D.F. soldiers took him into custody.
item.itunes:author: By Mosab Abu Toha
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: How the “No Kill” Movement Betrays Its Name
item.itunes:summary: By keeping cats outdoors, trap-neuter-release policies have troubling consequences for city residents, local wildlife—and even the cats themselves.
item.itunes:author: By Jonathan Franzen
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Has Gratuity Culture Reached a Tipping Point?
item.itunes:summary: Paying extra for service has inspired rebellions, swivelling iPads, and irritation from Trotsky. Post-pandemic, the practice has entered a new stage.
item.itunes:author: By Zach Helfand
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: How a Script Doctor Found His Own Voice
item.itunes:summary: For decades, Scott Frank earned up to three hundred thousand dollars a week rewriting other people’s screenplays—from “Saving Private Ryan” to “The Ring.” Finally, he decided to stop playing ventriloquist.
item.itunes:author: By Patrick Radden Keefe
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Adventures of a Teen-Age Wharf Rat
item.itunes:summary: After a peripatetic childhood, a young traveller finds his way on an ambitious journey gone badly awry.
item.itunes:author: By Jon Lee Anderson
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Did an Abortion Ban Cost a Young Texas Woman Her Life?
item.itunes:summary: As many conservatives hail the fall of Roe for saving unborn lives, high-risk pregnancy becomes even more perilous.
item.itunes:author: By Stephania Taladrid
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: A Drug-Decriminalization Fight Erupts in Oregon
item.itunes:summary: An ambitious law set forth a more humane way to address addiction. Then came the backlash.
item.itunes:author: By E. Tammy Kim
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Price of Netanyahu’s Ambition
item.itunes:summary: Amid war with Hamas, a hostage crisis, the devastation of Gaza, and Israel’s splintering identity, the Prime Minister seems unable to distinguish between his own interests and his country’s.
item.itunes:author: By David Remnick
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: How to Eat a Tire in a Year
item.itunes:summary: Walking and talking with my friend Dawn.
item.itunes:author: By David Sedaris
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Woman Who Spent Five Hundred Days in a Cave
item.itunes:summary: Beatriz Flamini liked to be alone so much that she decided to live underground—and pursue a world record. The experience was gruelling and surreal.
item.itunes:author: By D. T. Max
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Rules for the Ruling Class
item.itunes:summary: How to thrive in the power élite—while declaring it your enemy.
item.itunes:author: By Evan Osnos
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Is A.I. the Death of I.P.?
item.itunes:summary: Generative A.I. is the latest in a long line of innovations to put pressure on our already dysfunctional copyright system.
item.itunes:author: By Louis Menand
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Rural Ski Slope Caught Up in an International Scam
item.itunes:summary: A federal program promised to bring foreign investment to remote parts of the country. It soon became rife with fraud.
item.itunes:author: By Sheelah Kolhatkar
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Perverse Policies That Fuel Wildfires
item.itunes:summary: We thought we could master nature, but we were playing with fire.
item.itunes:author: By Elizabeth Kolbert
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Inside the Music Industry’s High-Stakes A.I. Experiments
item.itunes:summary: Lucian Grainge, the chairman of UMG, has helped record labels rake in billions of dollars from streaming. Can he do the same with generative artificial intelligence?
item.itunes:author: By John Seabrook
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Ukraine’s Democracy in Darkness
item.itunes:summary: With elections postponed and no end to the war with Russia in sight, Volodymyr Zelensky and his political allies are becoming like the officials they once promised to root out: entrenched.
item.itunes:author: By Masha Gessen
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: A Teen’s Fatal Plunge Into the London Underworld
item.itunes:summary: After Zac Brettler mysteriously plummeted into the Thames, his grieving parents were shocked to learn that he’d been posing as an oligarch’s son. Would the police help them solve the puzzle of his death?
item.itunes:author: By Patrick Radden Keefe
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: How Nikola Jokić Became the World’s Best Basketball Player
item.itunes:summary: He doesn’t run very fast or jump very high, and seems to prefer the company of horses. But he has mastered the game’s new geometry like nobody else.
item.itunes:author: By Louisa Thomas
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Raging Bill
item.itunes:summary: Bill Ackman’s fight against Harvard has made him the public face of a billionaire class anxious it no longer rules the world.
item.itunes:author: By Reeves Wiedeman
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Friendship Challenge
item.itunes:summary: How envy destroyed the perfect connection between two teen-age girls.
item.itunes:author: By Mary Gaitskill
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: An American Education
item.itunes:summary: Inside the Forbidden Courses at the billionaire-backed University of Austin, the campus of the anti woke commentariat.
item.itunes:author: By NOAH RAWLINGS
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Legal Weed in New York Was Going to Be a Revolution. What Happened?
item.itunes:summary: Lawsuits. Unlicensed dispensaries. Corporations pushing to get in. The messy rollout of a law that has tried to deliver social justice with marijuana.
item.itunes:author: By Jia Tolentino
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Snake with the Emoji-Patterned Skin
item.itunes:summary: In the wild, ball pythons are usually brown and tan. In America, breeding them to produce eye-catching offspring has become a lucrative, frenetic, and—for some—troubling enterprise.
item.itunes:author: By Rebecca Giggs
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: Matt Gaetz’s Chaos Agenda
item.itunes:summary: The Florida Republican is among the most brazen and controversial figures in Donald Trump’s G.O.P. He’s also among the most influential.
item.itunes:author: By Dexter Filkins
item.itunes:subtitle: foo

item.title: The Trials of Alejandro Mayorkas
item.itunes:summary: The Secretary of Homeland Security has been forced to respond to an unprecedented flow of migrants to the U.S.-Mexico border. Why are Republicans in Congress impeaching him for it?
item.itunes:author: By Jonathan Blitzer
item.itunes:subtitle: foo
